subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: New Thoughts about Read's Alphabets
msgSnippet: Hi again,I didn t realize the extent of thought others had on this.  I have now been thinking about using both Shaw s alphabet letters and QS in my own
messageBody:
Hi again,
I didn't realize the extent of thought others had on this.  I have now been thinking about using both Shaw's alphabet letters and QS in my own modified script of "Read's alphabets."

Some ideas that I got from other writers is that it is more cursive but cursive script has a tendency to break down when written fast anyway.  That is why the schools are teaching more of a print script.  We can also see this with Pitman and Gregg.  Unless the writer is very obsessive about shaping letters proportionally and using correct spacing between letters, words, lines, etc., there is not much to recommend cursive over print.  Print clearly is easier to read.

Secondly, any shorthand writer will develop their own way of abbreviating words.  It is difficult at times for another writer to read a modified script.  If QS and Shaw's alphabet is a shorthand of some kind, then alphabet shorthand would definitely be faster and easier to read.  On the other hand, how can QS or Shaw's alphabet compete with Greg or Pitman?

Thirdly, I had a deuce of a time learning both scripts.  The problem with Shaw's alphabet was the British accent - my accent is midwestern U.S.  Writing the scripts were easier for me than reading.  One might be curious to know that I speak a new language easier than understand it which is very difficult for me.

Anyway, I would ask this question of myself and whoever else wants to answer it:  What really is the purpose of Read's alphabets?  Shaw wanted a phonetic alphabet and more abbreviated so he could fit more letters on a page.  However, my sense was that the more abbreviated strokes often make one hesitate unless one is either accustomed to it or can take slight alterations of the letter in stride.

For example, the "uh" in kom in the QS could suffer from readability if written quickly in a cursive link.  The pause for readability would prevent fluid readability that would not be the case with an alphabet shorthand since we are more accustomed to the latin letters which are a bit more elaborated.

Frankly, I began to think of the alphabets as more of a secret code such as I use to get from old-time radio programs as Capt. Midnight, Jack Armstrong, etc.  I use it to write down what I would not want anyone else to read or know about which is really not often.

My own experience in correspondence was that it was brief.  I wrote to a man in New Zealand for awhile but unless one has a particular common interest in some matter the correspondence begins to wear thin after awhile.  

The last point about not being a purist about Read's alphabets is that others -- I believe it was Mr. Page, was it not? who developed a revised version of Read's alphabet which I was tempted to send for.  And, I have noticed even in Esperanto that "x" I believe became a "ch" character that Zamenhoff did not create at the time it became popular.  My point here is that human nature likes to tinker with such matters -- languages change, alphabets get altered, etc.  

It might be if there is enough interest that some people will get together and in some way try to integrate both Shaw's alphabet and QS or accept a further revision of Read's work.  I don't think it would be a heresy to take an interest in the advantages, if any, in adopting a more practical or aesthetic approach.   The point here of my own interest is whether his language creations have benefits that have not been thoroughly covered

Sid

--- On Fri, 8/19/11, Sid Tanaban <sidban2@...> wrote:

From: Sid Tanaban <sidban2@...>
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: I'd like to be able to write the prefixes com- and con- as contractions
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Date: Friday, August 19, 2011, 8:04 PM

 

Mr. Read was quite willing to abandon the Shaw's alphabet and use other letters that he thought more suitable.  It was his opinion -- not a scientific rule!  My opinion would be if you do not like "o" then use the "uh" of Shaw's alphabet.  Actually, I recognize that very easily.  I studied Shaw's alphabet before QS and think some of the letters are much more aesthetically drawn.  And, that would be my viewpoint about other questions about such a matter.  Mr. Read may or may not have been dogmatic about what he created but it is really preferable for your own use to choose what is delightful and easy to read.  After all, do you want to view this as one would view the Bible?  The script is only a tool for one's own pleasure and surely a minor change is not going to harm readability, particularly when everyone is sounding out these words according to their own particular use of English anyway.

I am sure someone will object to what I have to say and I would be curious if someone feels that there is something I have overlooked.  If so, please convey your thought on it.
Sid

--- On Fri, 8/19/11, cossyrosario <cossyrosario@...> wrote:

From: cossyrosario <cossyrosario@...>
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: I'd like to be able to write the prefixes com- and con- as contractions
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Date: Friday, August 19, 2011, 12:28 PM

 

What is T.O.?
Traditional Orthodox? (equivalent to Latin letters?)

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "C. Paige Gabhart" <pgabhart@...>
wrote:
>
>
>
> I would recommend against using an "o" even for a private
"work-around"
> when that is not the sound needed for the word. In my opinion, you
want
> to indelibly link the QS letters with the sounds they represent in
your
> mind to foster automatic reading, i.e. without the necessity of
sounding
> out words. After all, this is what we do with T.O.
>
> I think the use of a letter that represents a different sound in place
> of the correct letter, would be counter productive and harmful to your
> comprehension. I would just advise you to realize that QS does not
> require that every letter be joined to every other letter. QS is
quite
> cursive as Read designed it. The small amount of time required for
the
> occasional pen-lift, is not worth the confusion of muddying the
phonemic
> character, might I say, "purity," of the alphabet.
>
> Just my two cents.
>
>
> Paige Gabhart
>
>
> On 8/18/2011 12:12 PM, cossyrosario wrote:
> >
> > Thanks, Sid.
> >
> > The reason why I didn't use this work-around is because I've been
> > trying to follow the QuikScript rule that the letters represent
> > /sounds/ of the English language.
> >
> > In com- con- the o sound is like the u in utter (as in commend,
> > contend), or like the o in ox (compliment, conscious). The o when
> > written as in Latin letters (as a circle) has the sound of owe in
owe.
> > Therefore com- with the circle o would rhyme with comb, and con-
with
> > the circle o would rhyme with cone, which is not what I want to.
> >
> > However, if I were making notes for myself, as is the case most of
the
> > time I use QuikScript, I could certainly use the o as a private
> > work-around.
> >
> > What I have been using as an even shorter work-around for temporary
> > private notes (to-do list, notes of a meeting discussion to be
> > transcribed fairly soon on the computer) is just the k as a prefix,
> > thus kputer for computer, kshus for conscious, etc.
> >
> >
> > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Sid Tanaban sidban2@ wrote:
> > >
> > > com or con can be written in one stroke. Â Just write the "o"
as you
> > would in latin letters and add the "m" Â Unfortunately, I have
no
> > idea how to do this on a computer.
> > > Sid
> > >
> > > --- On Wed, 8/17/11, cossyrosario cossyrosario@ wrote:
> > >
> > > From: cossyrosario cossyrosario@

> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > Thank you, Steve!
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > In my hurry to learn as much as possible as soon as possible, I
raced
> > >
> > > through the manual, and must have raced past the section on com-
con- as
> > >
> > > it must have seemed obvious, with nothing new to learn! Or so it
must
> > >
> > > have seemed at the time.
> > >

thoroughly covered

---428857371-1130302293-1313811727=:50446
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

<table cellspacing=3D"0" cellpadding=3D"0" border=3D"0" ><tr><td valign=3D"=
top" style=3D"font: inherit;">Hi again,<div>I didn't realize the extent of =
thought others had on this.  I have now been thinking about using both=
 Shaw's alphabet letters and QS in my own modified script of "Read's alphab=
ets."</div><div><br></div><div>Some ideas that I got from other writers is =
that it is more cursive but cursive script has a tendency to break down whe=
n written fast anyway.  That is why the schools are teaching more of a=
 print script.  We can also see this with Pitman and Gregg.  Unle=
ss the writer is very obsessive about shaping letters proportionally and us=
ing correct spacing between letters, words, lines, etc., there is not much =
to recommend cursive over print.  Print clearly is easier to read.</di=
v><div><br></div><div>Secondly, any shorthand writer will develop their own=
 way of abbreviating words.  It is difficult at times for another writ=
er
 to read a modified script.  If QS and Shaw's alphabet is a shortha=
nd of some kind, then alphabet shorthand would definitely be faster and eas=
ier to read.  On the other hand, how can QS or Shaw's alphabet compete=
 with Greg or Pitman?</div><div><br></div><div>Thirdly, I had a deuce of a =
time learning both scripts.  The problem with Shaw's alphabet was the =
British accent - my accent is midwestern U.S.  Writing the scripts wer=
e easier for me than reading.  One might be curious to know that I spe=
ak a new language easier than understand it which is very difficult for me.=
</div><div><br></div><div>Anyway, I would ask this question of myself and w=
hoever else wants to answer it:  What really is the purpose of Read's =
alphabets?  Shaw wanted a phonetic alphabet and more abbreviated so he=
 could fit more letters on a page.  However, my sense was that the mor=
e abbreviated strokes often make one hesitate unless one is either
 accusto=
med to it or can take slight alterations of the letter in stride.</div><div=
><br></div><div>For example, the "uh" in kom in the QS could suffer from re=
adability if written quickly in a cursive link.  The pause for readabi=
lity would prevent fluid readability that would not be the case with an alp=
habet shorthand since we are more accustomed to the latin letters which are=
 a bit more elaborated.</div><div><br></div><div>Frankly, I began to think =
of the alphabets as more of a secret code such as I use to get from old-tim=
e radio programs as Capt. Midnight, Jack Armstrong, etc.  I use it to =
write down what I would not want anyone else to read or know about which is=
 really not often.</div><div><br></div><div>My own experience in correspond=
ence was that it was brief.  I wrote to a man in New Zealand for awhil=
e but unless one has a particular common interest in some matter the corres=
pondence begins to wear thin after awhile.
  </div><div><br></div><div=
>The last point about not being a purist about Read's alphabets is that oth=
ers -- I believe it was Mr. Page, was it not? who developed a revised versi=
on of Read's alphabet which I was tempted to send for.  And, I have no=
ticed even in Esperanto that "x" I believe became a "ch" character that Zam=
enhoff did not create at the time it became popular.  My point here is=
 that human nature likes to tinker with such matters -- languages change, a=
lphabets get altered, etc.  </div><div><br></div><div>It might be if t=
here is enough interest that some people will get together and in some way =
try to integrate both Shaw's alphabet and QS or accept a further revision o=
f Read's work.  I don't think it would be a heresy to take an interest=
 in the advantages, if any, in adopting a more practical or aesthetic appro=
ach.   The point here of my own interest is whether his language creat=
ions have benefits that have not
 been thoroughly covered</div><div><br></d=
iv><div>Sid<br><br>--- On <b>Fri, 8/19/11, Sid Tanaban <i><sidban2@yahoo=
.com></i></b> wrote:<br><blockquote style=3D"border-left: 2px solid rgb(=
16, 16, 255); margin-left: 5px; padding-left: 5px;"><br>From: Sid Tanaban &=
lt;sidban2@...><br>Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: I'd like to be=
 able to write the prefixes com- and con- as contractions<br>To: Read_Alpha=
bet@yahoogroups.com<br>Date: Friday, August 19, 2011, 8:04 PM<br><br><div i=
d=3D"yiv1173927453">













 
<span style=3D"display:none;"> </s=
pan>



    <div id=3D"yiv1173927453ygrp-text">
      
      
      <p><tab=
le cellspacing=3D"0" cellpadding=3D"0" border=3D"0"><tbody><tr><td valign=
=3D"top" style=3D"font:inherit;">Mr. Read was quite willing to abandon the =
Shaw's alphabet and use other letters that he thought more suitable.  =
It was his opinion -- not a scientific rule!  My opinion would be if y=
ou do not like "o" then use the "uh" of Shaw's alphabet.  Actually, I =
recognize that very easily.  I studied Shaw's alphabet before QS and t=
hink some of the letters are much more aesthetically drawn.  And, that=
 would be my viewpoint about other questions about such a matter.  Mr.=
 Read may or may not have been dogmatic about what he created but it is rea=
lly preferable for your own use to choose what is delightful and easy to re=
ad.  After all, do you want to view this as one would view the Bible? =
 The script is only a tool for one's own pleasure and surely a minor c=
hange is not going to harm readability, particularly when everyone
 is soun=
ding
 out these words according to their own particular use of English anyw=
ay.<div><br></div><div>I am sure someone will object to what I have to say =
and I would be curious if someone feels that there is something I have over=
looked.  If so, please convey your thought on it.</div><div>Sid<br><br=
>--- On <b>Fri, 8/19/11, cossyrosario <i><cossyrosario@...></=
i></b> wrote:<br><blockquote style=3D"border-left:2px solid rgb(16, 16, 255=
);"><br>From: cossyrosario <cossyrosario@...><br>Subject: [Re=
ad_Alphabet] Re: I'd like to be able to write the prefixes com- and con- as=
 contractions<br>To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com<br>Date: Friday, August =
19, 2011, 12:28 PM<br><br><div id=3D"yiv1173927453">













 
<span>&=
nbsp;</span>



    <div id=3D"yiv1173927453ygrp-text">
      
      
     =
 <p>What is T.O.?<br>
Traditional Orthodox? (equivalent to Latin letters?)<=
br>
<br>
--- In <a rel=3D"nofollow">Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com</a>, "C. =
Paige Gabhart" <pgabhart@...><br>
wrote:<br>
><br>
><br>
><b=
r>
> I would recommend against using an "o" even for a private<br>
"work=
-around"<br>
> when that is not the sound needed for the word.  In my op=
inion, you<br>
want<br>
> to indelibly link the QS letters with the soun=
ds they represent in<br>
your<br>
> mind to foster automatic reading, i.=
e. without the necessity of<br>
sounding<br>
> out words.  After all, th=
is is what we do with T.O.<br>
><br>
> I think the use of a letter th=
at represents a different sound in place<br>
> of the correct letter, wo=
uld be counter productive and harmful to your<br>
> comprehension.  I wo=
uld just advise you to realize that QS does not<br>
> require that every=
 letter be joined to every other letter.  QS is<br>
quite<br>
> cursive =
as Read designed it.  The small amount of time required for<br>
the<br>
&gt=
; occasional pen-lift, is not worth the confusion of muddying the<br>
phone=
mic<br>
> character, might I say, "purity," of the alphabet.<br>
><br=
>
> Just my two cents.<br>
><br>
><br>
> Paige Gabhart<br>
>=

><br>

> ><br>
> > The reason why I di=
dn't use this work-around is because I've been<br>
> > trying to foll=
ow the QuikScript rule that the letters represent<br>
> > /sounds/ of=
 the English language.<br>
> ><br>
> > In com- con- the o sound=
 is like the u in utter (as in commend,<br>
> > contend), or like the=
 o in ox (compliment, conscious). The o when<br>
> > written as in La=
tin letters (as a circle) has the sound of owe in<br>
owe.<br>
> > Th=
erefore com- with the circle o would rhyme with comb, and con-<br>
with<br>=

> > the circle o would rhyme with cone, which is not what I want to.=
<br>
> ><br>
> > However, if I were making notes for myself, as=
 is the case most of<br>
the<br>
> > time I use QuikScript, I could c=
ertainly use the o as a private<br>
> > work-around.<br>
> ><br=
>

rary<br>
> > private notes (to-do list, notes of a meeting discussion=
 to be<br>
> > transcribed fairly soon on the computer) is just the k=
 as a prefix,<br>
> > thus kputer for computer, kshus for conscious, =
etc.<br>
